repnme.cdata!:
Yugoslavia, Federal Republic of - Emergency
            Stabilization of Electricity Supply in the Republic of
            Montenegro Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Stabilization
            of Electricity Supply in the Republic of Montenegro Project
            for Yugoslavia were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was low or negligible, the
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            Application of modern metering technology provides utilities
            suffering from high network losses and poor collections with
            a means of mitigating these problems. However for any
            metering project to be effective, it will be accompanied
            with an investment program of rehabilitation of Latvia (LV)
            networks and feeders where the metering project is
            implemented. Given the associated cost of modern metering
            and network rehabilitation, utilities are advised to
            gradually expand new metering technology in areas that will
            yield the highest benefits as determined by a cost/benefit
            analysis performed for the metering project. To avoid delays
            in project implementation, adequate time and effort is
            required to develop a suitable design for a proper metering
            system, tender packages, the bid evaluation process, and to
            develop a realistic plan for project implementation.
            Significant costs will be associated with the initial stage
            of an automatic meter reading (AMR) System project. However,
            costs of subsequent scale up stages of the AMR system may be
            lower due to increased implementation efficiency by utility
            staff and the economies of scale.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Serbia, Republic of Montenegro
            - Legal Amendments and Assumption of Responsibilities :
            second order restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            the Regional Vice President, Europe and Central Asia Region,
            to the Republic of Montenegro assuming responsibilities
            currently held by the Republic of Serbia, for loans, credits
            and grant related to the Republic of Montenegro
            (Montenegro), after Montenegro becomes a member of the World
            Bank, scheduled for January 18, 2007. Activities for which
            Montenegro will need to assume responsibilities include
            three IBRD loans (so-called Consolidation Loans) which were
            taken by the FRY in 2001, nine IDA credits, and four trust
            fund grants. Obligations related to the IBRD loans consist
            of principal, interest and other charges repayment. The
            proposed changes will result in Montenegro assuming formal
            responsibility for implementation, reporting, fiduciary and
            repayment and other associated obligations attached to the
            loans, credits and grants involved.

repnme.cdata!:
Yugoslavia, Federal Republic of - Emergency
            Stabilization of Electricity Supply in the Republic of
            Montenegro Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main purpose of the Emergency
            Stabilization of Electricity Supply in the Republic of
            Montenegro Project, is to test the viability of, and the
            degree electric power distribution consumers demonstrate in
            improving their payment discipline. The Project will also
            participate in a loss reduction program in response to the
            introduction of remote metering, automated billing, and
            demand side management (DSM) in the pilot areas. The
            learning expectations to be documented through this pilot
            include the economic, and financial impacts of the
            distribution program; the distribution of automated
            technologies; the impact of changes on the institutional
            capacity of the Electric Power Company of Montenegro (EPCG);
            and, the social responsiveness to alternative service
            practices. The two main components will: 1) provide funds
            for the supply, and installation of equipment required for
            the provision of remote metering, automated billing, and DSM
            in selected areas. Technical assistance (TA) will be
            provided for the design, procurement, training, and
            implementation of pilot projects, as well as for monitoring
            and evaluation; and, 2) finance the supply, and installation
            of a computer-based management information system (MIS) in
            EPCG, which also includes TA for its design, procurement,
            training and implementation.
